International Restrictions:
*All travellers: There are no restrictions for foreign nationals to enter and leave Belarus, including through a land border, with exception of the Russia /Belarus state border. If you plan to enter or exit Belarus by land, check the travel advice of the relevant neighbouring country, as coronavirus-related restrictions may be put in place at short notice.
Some flights continue to operate out of Minsk and regional airports as normal, although at present there are no direct flights to destinations in western Europe.
You’ll need to have valid medical insurance before travelling to Belarus. You’ll be asked to provide proof of your insurance when you apply for your visa or on arrival at Minsk, Brest, Vitebsk, Gomel, Grodno and Mogilev airports under the 30 day visa-free regime.
If you’re fully vaccinated: If you’re fully vaccinated, you can enter Belarus without needing to test or quarantine. Your second dose must have been administered more than 1 but less than 12 months before arrival.
Proof of vaccination status: You must present proof that you have been fully vaccinated to enter Belarus.
You can use the COVID Pass to demonstrate your vaccination record when entering Belarus. However, your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination. Your COVID-19 certificate must be printed and either in Belarusian, Russian or English.
If you’re not fully vaccinated: If you’re not fully vaccinated, you’ll need to show proof of a negative PCR test (taken no more than 72 hours before entry) when entering Belarus. Foreign arrivals below the age of 6 are exempt from this requirement. This requirement does not apply to holders of permanent or temporary residency in Belarus.
There is no quarantine requirement. If you’ve had COVID-19 in the past year: If you’re not fully vaccinated but have tested positive for COVID-19 in the last year you will still need to provide a medical PCR certificate showing a negative coronavirus test result, issued no later than 72 hours before entry.
Residents of Belarus: Holders of permanent or temporary residency in Belarus do not need to show proof of PCR or vaccination to enter Belarus.
Children and young people: Children aged 6 and under do not need to show proof of PCR or vaccination to enter Belarus.
If you’re transiting through Belarus: Transiting is when you pass through one country on the way to your final destination. There is no need to self-isolate or provide a negative coronavirus test certificate for foreign nationals who plan to transit Belarus within 24 hours and provide evidence they will exit within this time-frame. For transfers over 24 hours, the advice above applies.
Exemptions: Holders of permanent or temporary residency in Belarus do not need to show proof of PCR or vaccination to enter Belarus. As noted above, children aged 6 and under do not need to provide proof of vaccination or PCR.

Internal restrictions:
*Travel, accommodation, public places and services in Belarus: There are no current coronavirus restrictions for travel or accommodation in Belarus.
*If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
